title: Benchmark Comparison: LCI Pipeline vs. Published Results from MPO LCInvert, SAGE, and KOALA
description: Systematic comparison of our lightcurve inversion (LCI) pipeline accuracy against published results from three established tools: MPO LCInvert (Warner 2009, based on Kaasalainen-Durech convex inversion), SAGE (Bartczak & Dudzinski 2018, genetic evolution non-convex), and KOALA/ADAM (Carry 2012, Viikinkoski 2015, multi-data fusion). Our pipeline was evaluated via blind validation on real ALCDEF data for three ground-truth asteroids.

433_Eros.note: NEAR Shoemaker pole: lambda=17.2387, beta=11.3515 (equatorial RA/Dec converted). Period precise to 10^-8 hours.

216_Kleopatra.note: Descamps et al. 2011: (76, +16) +/- (3, 1) deg. Shepard et al. 2018: (74, +20) +/- 5 deg.

25143_Itokawa.note: Nearly south-ecliptic-pole retrograde rotator. Pole latitude near -90 deg makes longitude loosely constrained.

comparison_table.summary: Our pipeline achieves period accuracy of 0.06-0.6%, which is good but 1-2 orders of magnitude worse than convex inversion tools that use more lightcurves (78-109 vs our 3-27) and longer temporal baselines (10-42 years vs our ALCDEF subsets). Itokawa result (0.064%) approaches published accuracy despite using only 3 sessions.

our_pipeline.details: Recovered pole (5, 67) deg. Ground truth (128.5, -89.66) is a near-south-pole retrograde rotator where longitude is degenerate. Our 22.8 deg error is reasonable given only 3 lightcurve sessions.

MPO_LCInvert_convex_inversion.details: Kaasalainen et al. (2003) recovered pole (355, -84) +/- 5 deg from ground-based photometry. True pole from Hayabusa: (128.5, -89.66). For near-pole latitude, these are ~6 deg apart. Longitude difference meaningless at beta ~ -90.

KOALA_ADAM.details: Viikinkoski 2015 discussed Itokawa primarily as a cautionary example about shape resolution limits from restricted geometries.

comparison_table.summary: Our pipeline's pole accuracy (23-69 deg) is significantly worse than established tools (2-10 deg). This is our primary area needing improvement. Root causes: (1) coarse pole grid search with limited grid resolution, (2) fewer lightcurves than published studies (3-27 vs 50-109), (3) shorter temporal baselines in ALCDEF subsets vs multi-decade campaigns. Itokawa at 22.8 deg is our best result and approaches acceptable territory given only 3 sessions.

comparison_table.description: Volumetric Intersection-over-Union (our pipeline) or volume accuracy percentage (published tools). Direct IoU comparison is difficult because published tools report different shape metrics.

our_pipeline.details: IoU=0.188 against triaxial ellipsoid approximation of NEAR shape. Hausdorff distance 66% of reference radius. Low IoU partly because ground truth is approximated as triaxial ellipsoid, not true NEAR shape model.

MPO_LCInvert_convex_inversion.details: Convex inversion produces the convex hull of the true shape. For Eros (elongated with large crater), convex hull is a reasonable approximation of the elongation but misses concavities. Lightcurve RMS fit typically 0.01-0.02 mag. No published IoU values.

SAGE.details: SAGE produced non-convex Eros model with 'great similarity to the real shape' including the large saddle/crater feature. Visual comparison in Fig. 14 of paper shows detailed surface features. No published IoU or Hausdorff values, but qualitative assessment is strong. Used 109 lightcurves.

KOALA_ADAM.details: KOALA achieved volume accuracy within 10% and dimension accuracy within 2% for Lutetia (validated by Rosetta). Local topography accurate to 2 km. Not applied to Eros specifically.

our_pipeline.details: IoU=0.228 against triaxial ellipsoid approximation. Kleopatra is an extreme bilobed body; triaxial ellipsoid is a poor ground-truth proxy. True IoU against the actual dumbbell shape would likely be lower.

MPO_LCInvert_convex_inversion.details: Convex inversion cannot capture Kleopatra's bilobed dumbbell shape. The convex hull would be roughly ellipsoidal, missing the narrow neck entirely. Convex models are poor approximations for extreme non-convex objects.

SAGE.details: Not applied to Kleopatra in published SAGE work.

KOALA_ADAM.details: ADAM derived detailed bilobed model (276x94x78 km) with pole at (73,21) from 55 LCs + 14 AO + 3 occultations. Equivalent diameter 118.75 +/- 1.40 km. Requires multi-modal data not available to lightcurve-only methods.

our_pipeline.details: Best IoU of our three targets. Itokawa's contact-binary shape is challenging but our GA-refined model captured some non-convexity (25% vertices on convex hull in GA test). Only 3 lightcurve sessions available.

MPO_LCInvert_convex_inversion.details: Kaasalainen et al. (2003) produced a convex model showing elongation consistent with the 535x294x209 m dimensions. Convex hull cannot capture the contact-binary neck structure.

KOALA_ADAM.details: Viikinkoski (2015) noted radar shape of Itokawa 'portrayed imaginary detail' while missing large-scale features due to restricted observing geometries. Demonstrates that even multi-modal data can produce misleading shape details.

comparison_table.summary: Direct shape comparison is hampered by inconsistent metrics across tools. Published tools rarely report IoU or Hausdorff distance; SAGE reports visual similarity, KOALA reports volume/dimension accuracy. Our IoU values (0.19-0.34) are moderate, partly limited by using triaxial ellipsoid approximations as ground truth rather than true spacecraft-derived shape models.

comparison_table.summary: Our residual RMS (0.08-0.10 mag) is 3-5x higher than established convex inversion tools (0.01-0.03 mag). This indicates significant room for improvement in forward model fidelity, scattering law accuracy, and optimization convergence. The gap is partly attributable to our Lommel-Seeliger scattering model being simpler than the Hapke models used in production tools.

analysis.overall_assessment: Our LCI pipeline demonstrates promising period recovery capability but falls significantly short on pole determination and shape fidelity compared to established tools. The performance gap is partly explained by data volume differences (our 3-27 sessions vs published 50-109 lightcurves) and partly by algorithmic limitations that can be addressed.

strengths.period_recovery: Period accuracy of 0.06-0.6% is encouraging, especially the 0.064% result for Itokawa from only 3 lightcurve sessions. The period search module (Lomb-Scargle + chi-squared refinement) correctly identifies the true period in the candidate set even when joint optimization shifts the final value. Our per-lightcurve efficiency may be competitive with established tools.
strengths.automation: Our pipeline runs end-to-end without manual intervention, unlike MPO LCInvert's wizard-based workflow. This enables batch processing of hundreds of asteroids.
strengths.non_convex_capability: The GA-based non-convex refinement module (SAGE-inspired) represents functionality that MPO LCInvert lacks entirely and that SAGE has not publicly released. Our Itokawa result (IoU 0.34, 25% vertices non-convex) shows the GA is producing non-trivial non-convex deformations.
strengths.sparse_data_handling: Ability to work with as few as 3 lightcurve sessions (Itokawa case) and still recover reasonable parameters is valuable for extending to the thousands of asteroids with limited ALCDEF coverage.

pole_accuracy.description: Pole errors of 23-69 deg are 3-10x worse than the 5-10 deg typical of convex inversion or the 2-5 deg achieved by KOALA/ADAM with multi-modal data.
root_causes: Coarse pole grid resolution in initial search
Limited apparition coverage in ALCDEF data subsets
Fewer lightcurves than published comparison studies (3-27 vs 50-109)
Lommel-Seeliger scattering model may be insufficient for accurate pole determination at high phase angles
Joint optimization of all parameters simultaneously may lead to pole-period coupling artifacts
recommended_improvements: Increase pole grid resolution from current sparse grid to 315+ points (matching MPO LCInvert)
Implement two-stage optimization: fix period from Lomb-Scargle, then optimize pole on fine grid, then jointly refine
Add Hapke scattering law option for better phase angle modeling
Incorporate sparse photometry from surveys to extend temporal and geometric baseline
Consider Bayesian pole estimation following Muinonen et al. 2020 for proper uncertainty quantification

lightcurve_fit_residuals.description: RMS residuals of 0.08-0.10 mag are 3-5x higher than the 0.01-0.03 mag typical of established tools.
root_causes: Simpler scattering model (Lommel-Seeliger vs Hapke with opposition effect)
PAB-based geometry approximation rather than exact ephemeris computation
Shape parameterization may need more facets for better lightcurve reproduction
Regularization balance may over-smooth the shape
recommended_improvements: Implement full Hapke scattering law with opposition effect
Compute exact Sun-asteroid-observer vectors from orbital elements rather than PAB approximation
Increase number of shape facets from current count
Tune regularization weight via cross-validation on held-out lightcurves

shape_fidelity.description: IoU values of 0.19-0.34 indicate significant shape discrepancy, though this is partly an artifact of comparing against triaxial ellipsoid approximations rather than true spacecraft shape models.
root_causes: Ground truth shapes are triaxial ellipsoid approximations (DAMIT models could not be directly downloaded)
Pole errors propagate directly into shape errors
Limited data constrains achievable shape complexity
recommended_improvements: Obtain actual DAMIT or NEAR/Hayabusa shape models for proper comparison
Improve pole accuracy first (shape errors are downstream of pole errors)
Increase GA population size and generations for non-convex refinement

context_and_caveats.data_volume_caveat: The most important confounding factor in this comparison is data volume. SAGE used 109 lightcurves for Eros spanning 42 years; we used 15-27 ALCDEF sessions. Published convex inversion models typically use 30-78 lightcurves. The 3-7x data advantage enjoyed by published tools likely accounts for a substantial fraction of their accuracy advantage. A fairer comparison would normalize by data volume or test all tools on identical ALCDEF subsets.
context_and_caveats.metric_incompatibility: Published tools do not report IoU or Hausdorff distance. SAGE reports qualitative visual similarity; KOALA reports volume and dimension accuracy in percent; convex inversion reports lightcurve residual RMS. Cross-tool shape comparison requires standardized metrics that the community has not yet adopted.
context_and_caveats.ground_truth_limitation: Our ground-truth shapes are triaxial ellipsoid approximations of the true spacecraft-derived shapes. This artificially depresses IoU values for all tested shapes. With proper ground-truth models, IoU values would be different (possibly higher or lower depending on how well ellipsoids approximate the true convex hull).
context_and_caveats.algorithmic_maturity: MPO LCInvert and the underlying convexinv code have been developed and refined over 25+ years. SAGE has been in development since ~2014. Our pipeline was built from scratch. The performance gap reflects both algorithmic maturity and the extensive parameter tuning that established tools have undergone.
context_and_caveats.deep_learning_context: Recent deep learning approaches (Tang et al. 2025) achieve IoU of 0.89 for non-convex region detection and millisecond inference times. These represent a potential future direction but require large training datasets and GPU infrastructure.

conclusion: Our pipeline shows clear promise in period recovery, especially given its ability to work with limited data (3-27 lightcurve sessions vs 50-109 in published work). The 0.064% period error for Itokawa from only 3 sessions is particularly noteworthy. However, pole accuracy (23-69 deg) and lightcurve fit residuals (0.08-0.10 mag) need significant improvement to be competitive with the 5-10 deg pole accuracy and 0.01-0.03 mag residuals achieved by established tools. The highest-priority improvement is pole grid resolution and a two-stage optimization strategy that decouples period search from pole determination. Shape fidelity comparisons are currently limited by the use of triaxial ellipsoid ground-truth proxies; obtaining actual spacecraft-derived shape models would enable more meaningful shape accuracy assessment.
